schema_place.name: Glastenbury Mountain
schema_place.description: Glastenbury Mountain is a 3,748 foot peak in Vermont offering hiking trails with scenic views.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to hike Glastenbury Mountain?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most routes on Glastenbury Mountain take 11-13 hours round trip. The most popular trail is 22.0 miles with Hard difficulty. Start early, especially on weekends when parking fills quickly.

mainEntity.name: Is Glastenbury Mountain hard to hike?

acceptedAnswer.text: Glastenbury Mountain is rated Hard. At 3,748 feet, the trail offers a rewarding hike suitable for most fitness levels. Proper footwear and preparation are essential.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a permit to hike Glastenbury Mountain?

acceptedAnswer.text: No hiking permit is required for Glastenbury Mountain. However, parking fees may apply at trailheads (typically $3-5/day for WMNF or state parks). A WMNF parking pass covers most White Mountain trailheads.

mainEntity.name: What is the best trail to hike Glastenbury Mountain?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most popular route is the Long Trail to Glastenbury, offering Remote Long Trail section to fire tower. Usually done as overnight..

mainEntity.name: When is the best time to hike Glastenbury Mountain?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best hiking season for Glastenbury Mountain is April through November. Spring wildflowers and fall foliage are particularly scenic.

page_content.description:
Rising to 3,748 feet, Glastenbury Mountain offers one of Vermont's finest hiking experiences. Whether you're seeking panoramic views, a family-friendly outing, or a quick escape into nature, this peak delivers.

Popular Routes

The most popular route, **Long Trail to Glastenbury**, covers 22.0 miles and is rated Hard. Remote Long Trail section to fire tower. Usually done as overnight.

Peak Bagging

**Extend Your Adventure:** Haystack Mountain lies just 7.7 miles away, making it an excellent addition for ambitious hikers looking to bag multiple summits.

spring.title: Spring Conditions
spring.tips: Trail closures for mud season (April-May). Check conditions before heading out.

summer.title: Summer Conditions
summer.tips: Start early to avoid afternoon storms and parking issues. Peak crowds on weekends.

fall.title: Fall Conditions
fall.tips: Peak foliage brings peak crowds. Weekday hikes recommended. Watch for ice above treeline in late October.

winter.title: Winter Conditions
winter.tips: Traction devices recommended. Start early for daylight.

current_hazards: Hypothermia risk - temperatures 20-40°F colder at summit
Trail markers may be buried under snow
